docs.abstract: The president is brazenly grabbing his only clear option to bolster his re-election hopes, portraying himself as a take-charge leader the country can’t afford to lose.
docs.snippet: The president is brazenly grabbing his only clear option to bolster his re-election hopes, portraying himself as a take-charge leader the country can’t afford to lose.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With the economy faltering and the political landscape unsettled as the coronavirus death toll climbs, a stark and unavoidable question now confronts President Trump and his advisers: Can he save his campaign for re-election when so much is suddenly going so wrong?

headline.main: ‘Wartime President’? Trump Rewrites History in an Election Year

byline.original: By Annie Karni, Maggie Haberman and Reid J. Epstein

docs.abstract: An aid bill advances, and President Trump wants to jump-start the economy: This is your morning tip sheet.
docs.snippet: An aid bill advances, and President Trump wants to jump-start the economy: This is your morning tip sheet.
docs.lead_paragraph: President Trump participated in a Fox News virtual town-hall-style event from the Rose Garden of the White House on Tuesday.

headline.main: On Politics: We Have a Deal

docs.abstract: The gap between the Trump campaign’s boosterism and the reality of a nation under siege from a deadly contagion can be jarring.
docs.snippet: The gap between the Trump campaign’s boosterism and the reality of a nation under siege from a deadly contagion can be jarring.
docs.lead_paragraph: On Sunday, hours before the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention warned against any gatherings of 50 people or more, a measure designed to slow the spread of the coronavirus, President Trump signed an email to his millions of supporters.

headline.main: What Coronavirus? Trump Campaign Plows Ahead Online With Talk of ‘WINNING Like Never Before’
headline.print_headline: Emails to Fans Avoid One Topic. Guess.

docs.abstract: The former New York mayor, announcing he would donate $18 million to the Democratic National Committee, abandoned a plan to employ his campaign organizers through November.
docs.snippet: The former New York mayor, announcing he would donate $18 million to the Democratic National Committee, abandoned a plan to employ his campaign organizers through November.
docs.lead_paragraph: Michael R. Bloomberg on Friday abandoned plans to form a new super PAC for the presidential race and employ his campaign organizers through November, instead opting to give $18 million to the Democratic National Committee for the party’s battleground states program and disband the army of field workers he had assembled across the country.

headline.main: ‘I’m So Sorry I Worked for This Guy’: Ex-Staffers React to Bloomberg Reversal on Field Organizers
headline.print_headline: Bloomberg, in a Reversal, Decides Against Starting a Super PAC

byline.original: By Rebecca R. Ruiz, Alexander Burns and Reid J. Epstein

docs.abstract: A nation ravaged by the Spanish flu figured out how to vote back then. Not without incident, but with democracy intact.
docs.snippet: A nation ravaged by the Spanish flu figured out how to vote back then. Not without incident, but with democracy intact.
docs.lead_paragraph: Across the country, citizens were ordered to hunker in their homes to avoid catching a deadly virus even as some people thought it was nothing worse than a seasonal cold. In the midst of fear and sickness, politicians had to decide how to hold scheduled elections, and the global pandemic was subject to political spin.

headline.main: The Lessons of the Elections of 1918
headline.print_headline: A Pandemic in an Election Year in a Divided U.S.: Welcome to 1918

docs.abstract: Party conventions are in jeopardy, campaigning is on hold and local candidates are playing the role of good Samaritan instead of traditional politician.
docs.snippet: Party conventions are in jeopardy, campaigning is on hold and local candidates are playing the role of good Samaritan instead of traditional politician.
docs.lead_paragraph: From the White House to the county courthouse, the coronavirus pandemic has drastically upended the 2020 elections.

headline.main: Is the U.S. Headed Toward a Short British-Style Election?
headline.print_headline: Politicians Test Novel Playbook For Era of Fear

byline.original: By Jonathan Martin, Reid J. Epstein and Maggie Haberman

docs.abstract: Defenders of property rights find something else they want to defend: Their own communities.
docs.snippet: Defenders of property rights find something else they want to defend: Their own communities.
docs.lead_paragraph: John Lowry vacationed in Door County, Wis., when he was a child. He loved it so much that 30 years ago he moved there. It’s not in his nature to tell people who share his fondness for what he calls “the Cape Cod of the Midwest” to please just stay away.

headline.main: ‘We are Trying to Protect Our Own’: The Towns Keeping Part-Timers Out
headline.print_headline: Full-Timers in Towns Full of Seasonal Homes Send Message: Keep Out

docs.abstract: Daily briefings during the crisis in New York have given Gov. Andrew Cuomo a captive audience, and a growing fan base. But he has made it clear that he’s not going anywhere.
docs.snippet: Daily briefings during the crisis in New York have given Gov. Andrew Cuomo a captive audience, and a growing fan base. But he has made it clear that he’s not going anywhere.
docs.lead_paragraph: His is a new coalition, couch-bound and spooked, finding small comforts where few had sought sustenance before: in the tender embrace of a disaster briefing by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo.

headline.main: What the ‘Cuomo 2020’ Fantasy Says About 2020 Reality
headline.print_headline: Stolid Briefings Elicit a Couch-Bound Fan Base’s Cry: ‘Cuomo for President’

docs.abstract: New ad buys reveal the key states where both parties think control of the Senate will be decided.
docs.snippet: New ad buys reveal the key states where both parties think control of the Senate will be decided.
docs.lead_paragraph: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Nick Corasaniti, your host on Tuesdays for our coverage of all things media and messaging.

headline.main: Where Are the Senate Battleground States? Look at the Ads

docs.abstract: After Bernie Sanders won New Hampshire and Nevada, his campaign hit a roadblock: a wide range of Democrats who would do anything to stop him. Joe Biden became their vehicle.
docs.snippet: After Bernie Sanders won New Hampshire and Nevada, his campaign hit a roadblock: a wide range of Democrats who would do anything to stop him. Joe Biden became their vehicle.
docs.lead_paragraph: Jane King, a financial investor from Boston who describes herself as progressive, began the presidential primary as an avowed supporter of Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts. But as Ms. Warren’s candidacy seemed to fade early this year, Ms. King looked elsewhere.

headline.main: How ‘Never Bernie’ Voters Threw In With Biden and Changed the Primary
headline.print_headline: With the Help of ‘Never Bernie’ Voters, Biden Solidified a Lead
